To be done before spreading
[Image]
[Image]
[Image]
[Image]
[Image]
INDICATION
Use in the field
Most types of fertiliser attract water and can thereby form large chunks. These chunks can block the spreader or distort the spreading pattern.
· When working under moist weather conditions, use a hopper cover that closes well.
· Do not spread without a hopper cover under moist conditions.
· Never leave the fertiliser for a long period of time in the spreader. Chunks can also be formed through moisture in the air.
· Always clean the spreader well after use, including the dosing openings and the discharge bushings.
You will most likely get into contact with the fertiliser and other material you may wish to spread while filling, adjusting and testing the spreader. Wear protective clothing and gloves, read the safety instructions provided by the supplier and follow their directions. Contact with these materials could cause physical harm.
Be careful that nothing gets jammed
It is easy for parts to get jammed while adjusting and checking the spreader.
Work safely while checking and adjusting:
· switching off the electronic control system,
· switch the tractor off and remove the key from the ignition,
· engage the parking brake of the tractor,
· wait for all machine parts to come to a standstill before you start with the adjustments,
· wear protective clothing, such as safety gloves and shoes,
· carefully follow the instructions given.
Friction with these materials could cause physical injury.
The distance between the discharge bushing and the spreading disc must be 1.0 mm.
If the distance is too great, the fertiliser does not flow through the discharge point opening onto the spreading disc but onto a random point below the discharge bushing. This results in a disrupted spreading pattern.
If the distance is too short, a full hopper may rest partly on the spreading disc, which seriously damages the machine as a result.
 Attach the empty machine and raise it to working height (75 cm).
 Switch the tractor off, remove the key from the ignition and engage the parking brake of the tractor.
 Place heavy, stable supports under the ends of the lifting arms.
 Lower the arms onto the supports. Now the machine cannot drop accidentally.
 Switch the tractor off, remove the key from the ignition and engage the parking brake of the tractor.
 Measure the distance between the spreading disc and the discharge bushing.
You can use a feeler gauge to measure short distances accurately.
If the measured distance is more or less than 1.0 mm, do the following:
 Remove the dashboard by loosening the 3 fixing knobs.
 Turn the lock nuts on the 4 fastening bolts with which the dosing mechanism is attached to the hopper a few times to loosen them.
 Move the discharge bushing upwards or downwards until the distance to the spreading disc is 1.0 mm.
You can also put 1.0 mm thick plates between the discharge bush and the spreading disc and lower the discharge bush onto them.
 Turn on the bolts attaching the discharge bushing to the agitator axle star.
 Check the height again and adjust it if necessary.
 Lower the dosing mechanism by turning the fastening bolt nuts upward.
Lower the dosing mechanism until the bayonet ring has moved halfway across the bolts attaching the discharge bushing to the star.
 Check the position of the dosing mechanism relative to the agitator axle. The distance between the agitator axle and the sealing ring must be the same on all sides.
===Page 166===

Maintenance
[Image]
Checking and setting the dosing mechanism
167
The dosing mechanism is now higher than the spreading disc and discharge bushing. Turn the dosing mechanism upwards until you have good access to the bolts attaching the discharge bushing to the agitator axle star.
 Unscrew the bolts attaching the discharge bush to the star a few times.
 Move the discharge bushing upwards or downwards until the distance to the spreading disc is 1.0 mm.
You can also put 1.0 mm thick plates between the discharge bush and the spreading disc and lower the discharge bush onto them.
 Turn on the bolts attaching the discharge bushing to the agitator axle star.
 Check the height again and adjust it if necessary.
 Lower the dosing mechanism by turning the fastening bolt nuts upward.
Lower the dosing mechanism until the bayonet ring has moved halfway across the bolts attaching the discharge bushing to the star.

results.question: What specific precaution should be taken before working between the tractor and machine to check the coupling shaft length?
results.expected_answer: Place the machine on a supporting beam.
results.model_answer:
The correct answer is: The coupling shaft must be cut to the correct length before connecting it to the tractor. A coupling shaft that is too long could lead to serious damage to the machine and the tractor.
The best way to check the coupling shaft length is by measuring with a tape measure or ruler, taking note of the minimum clearance between the PTO shaft and the machine drive axle, which should be at least 25 mm.

This will ensure that the machine cannot drop if the power lift should inadvertently be operated while you are between the tractor and machine. Switch also the tractor engine off and remove the keys from the ignition. Without the support, a power lift that drops could wedge you in, resulting in possible serious physical injury.
The maximum operating angle of the coupling shaft is 30 ° when lifted and 30 ° when lowered. This is the maximum length between the PTO shaft and the machine drive axle.

This is the shortest possible length between the two shafts.
A greater working angle could damage the coupling shaft.

results.question: What must be ensured with decoupling ropes during power lift connection?
results.expected_answer: Decoupling ropes must never be tense.
results.model_answer:
The coupling shaft must be extracted carefully to prevent damage to the machine and possible injury. The distance between the agitator axle and the seal ring must be 109 mm.
[Image]
165
===Page 166===

Coupling shaft with quick lock
[Image]
Agitator axle seal
170
The seal is damaged if the distance is not equal on all sides.
 Check that the agitator axle and the seal ring are in the same position.
 Remove the dashboard by loosening the 3 fixing knobs.
 Turn the nuts on the 4 fastening bolts with which the dosing mechanism is attached to the hopper a few times to loosen them. This will prevent damage to the machine and possible injury.
The seal must be replaced every season, as well as after every 100 operational hours.
If the distance between the agitator axle and the seal ring is not equal on all sides, do the following:
 Loosen the 2 bolts of the actuator plate slightly.
 Slide the actuator plate until the distance between the inside of the rope and the opening of the discharge bushing is 109 mm.
You can also put 1.0 mm thick plates between the discharge bush and the spreading disc and lower the discharge bush onto them.
 Turn on the bolts attaching the discharge bushing to the agitator axle star.
 Check the height again and adjust it if necessary.
 Lower the dosing mechanism by turning the fastening bolt nuts upward.
Lower the dosing mechanism until the bayonet ring has moved halfway across the bolts attaching the discharge bushing to the star.
 Check the position of the dosing mechanism relative to the agitator axle. The distance between the agitator axle and the sealing ring must be the same on all sides.

results.question: What is the general formula for calculating the required flowrate of fertilizer in kg/min?
results.expected_answer: Working width (m) x Driving speed (km/h) x Application rate (kg/ha) / 600
results.model_answer:
The general formula to calculate the required flowrate of fertiliser is:
flowrate = (kg/min) = Working width (m) x Driving speed (km/h) x Application rate (kg/ha)

This formula can be used for all types of fertilisers, including granules, seeds and pellets.

results.question: What does a tray test check on a fertilizer spreader?
results.expected_answer: Fertilizer distribution pattern of the spreader.
results.model_answer:
The exact spreading pattern is determined by the ExactLine system. The ExactLine system measures the distribution of fertiliser granules with a high degree of accuracy.
A tray test checks the distribution of the fertiliser in the spreader. The results of this test will indicate if you can improve the settings of the spreader, thereby improving the distribution of fertiliser and limiting loss.
The spreading pattern is normally a triangle that completely overlaps. A trapezium shape on very large working widths could cause the spreading patterns to overlap the most.
A tray test can be performed by specialised companies, but it is also possible to perform this test on your own. You will have to purchase some materials for it, however.
The ExactLine system provides a very good border spreading pattern with an optimal balance between profit and the environment.
The ExactLine has 'environment' and 'yield' settings for precisely adjusting border spreading.
[Image]
165
===Page 166===

To be done before spreading
Determining distribution
[Image]
[Image]
[Image]
[Image]
[Image]
The distribution is the ratio of granules with different diameters. A distribution meter comes with every spreader. This meter has 4 sections, with seven parts. The seven have different mesh width that divide the fertiliser granules, based on their diameters.
Distribution of 0-70-30-0 indicates none of the granules has a diameter of less than 2.0 mm, 70% have a diameter between 2.0 - 3.3 mm and none is larger than 4.75 mm.
You should therefore do the following to determine the distribution of the fertiliser with the distribution meter:
 Fill the slot that reads 4.75 mm and close the other openings with the cover.
 Close the distribution meter with the cover and keep it on its side.
 Shake it for as long as no more smaller granules are falling through the sieves.
 Turn the distribution meter back up and read the content of each slot. The given percentages should add up to 100%. It could be necessary to round the readings off with small and round granules.
TIP Fill the fraction meter from another part of the hopper in order to obtain a good average as the larger granules tend to roll to the outer part of the hopper.
TIP Clean the seven parts regularly in order to prevent them from getting blocked.
[Image]
The last figure indicates how you can read the following distribution: 0-70-30-0
Indication with regard to the distribution:
· If the diameter of 10% or more of the fertiliser granules is smaller than 2.0 mm, the fertiliser type would be difficult to spread, especially with large working widths. This could result in a less than optimal distribution and could damage the crops.
· If the diameter of 80 - 100% of the fertiliser granules is between 2.0 and 4.75 mm, the fertiliser would be good to spread, irrespective of the size of the remaining granules.
· If the diameter of 20% or more of the fertiliser granules is greater than 4.75 mm it would be difficult for optimum distribution. This could lead to damage to the crops as the granules could make holes in the leaves of the crop.
167
===Page 168===

Determining similar weight
[Image]
Finding the correct spreading chart
168
The density is the weight (kg) of 1 litre of fertiliser and it is expressed as kg/litre or ton/m3.
The following material is required to determine the density:
· measuring beaker (supplied),
· scale (supplied).
 Refer to the scale manual.
Working method to determine similar weight:
 Hang the empty and dry measuring beaker on the scale.
 Press the scale to 0.
 Fill the measuring beaker.
 Knock the measuring beaker 5 times on firm ground.
 Weigh the fertiliser.
 Repeat the steps above three times in order to determine the average weight.
Density of at least 1 kg/l is desirable for a good distribution of the fertiliser. Lighter types of fertiliser would be more difficult to spread and the maximum working width would be limited.
On the basis of the data you collected about your fertiliser, for the spreading chart of fertiliser with the best comparable properties and desired working width in the table of contents of your spreading chart book, or fill in the data through the online spreading chart service on the website or via the free application (App) for mobile phones.  see paragraph »Online spreading chart service« on page 61.
You can find the settings for the spreader, based on the application rate and the driving speed.
 See then paragraph »Setting the spreader« on page 62.
TIP the page indicated in the table of index of the spreading chart book indicates the settings for

results.question: What materials are required to perform the tray test?
results.expected_answer: A measuring tape or ruler, a spirit level, 7 troughs, 7 graduated tubes, a funnel, a notebook, pen, calculator, this manual, and the software's instruction manual.
results.model_answer:
The materials needed for performing a tray test include:
1. A measuring tape or ruler
2. Spirit level to set the troughs horizontal.
3. 7 troughs
4. A funnel into the graduated tubes.
5. A spirit level to check the height of the spreading disc.
6. A measuring beaker (supplied) and a scale (supplied).
7. The fertiliser for the tray test, seeds or granules.
8. A hopper extension is not required if the machine has a power lift.
9. A set of mud guards to protect the machine from being dirtied by the tractor wheels.
10. A step (optional) on the left and/or right side of the hopper.
11. The spreader must be placed at the correct height, 75 cm above the ground or crops.
12. The dosing units are closed properly.
13. The control system is switched off.
14. The PTO shaft is switched off.
15. The tractor is turned off and the key is removed from the ignition.
16. The parking brake of the tractor is engaged.
17. The machine is placed on a firm, level ground.
18. The dosing units are closed properly.
19. The control system is switched off.
20. The PTO shaft is disconnected.
21. The spreader is raised to working height (75 cm).

results.question: What happens when hopper content falls below 100 kg?
results.model_answer:
The machine will not spread evenly if the hopper content is less than 100 kg.
[Image]
166
===Page 167===

What happens when hopper content falls below 100 kg?
[Image]
When the hopper content is less than 100 kg, the control system switches off the automatic calibration. Measurement accuracy declines in such a way that new automatic calibration cannot produce a better discharge curve.
The distributed quantity can therefore not be correctly weighed if the hopper is filled while spreading. The weight in the hopper could even increase during the measurement period. The correction performed by the control system would be inaccurate as a result, which could lead to crop damage.

1. The first function is to provide a manual calibration test for the spreader.

These two functions can be used together or separately, depending on your needs.
The machine must be calibrated before use with the correct settings from the spreading chart.

results.question: What two actions must be done in the event of spreader failure or stoppage while using the spreader in the field?
results.expected_answer: Stop spreading immediately and disconnect the PTO shaft immediately.
results.model_answer:
The two actions to be taken are:
1. Check if the dosing mechanism is not set correctly.
2. Switch off the electronic control system and the tractor off, remove the key from the ignition and engage the parking brake of the tractor.

These steps will prevent damage to the machine and possible injury.

166
===Page 167===

Checking the hydraulic system
[Image]
[Image]
[Image]
[Image]
[Image]
Maintenance
Hydraulic oil is under high pressure
Never try to stop a leak with your fingers. Never try to locate a hydraulic leak or try to contain it by hand! When inspecting always use appropriate aid (e.g. a piece of wood or sheet metal) and wear safety goggles, safety gloves and gloves!
High pressure fluid easily penetrates skin and clothes, causing severe injuries. In the event of injury, contact your physician immediately!
Do not exceed the maximum hydraulic pressure of 210 bars
Prevent the pressure in the hydraulic system from exceeding 210 bars! Working above the permitted pressure may damage your machine and result in dangerous situations.
Keep your distance from the hydraulics during inspecting and test running
Use a stick to bend the hydraulic hoses when checking them for leakage. That way you will keep at sufficient distance. Oil jets or hoses that snap back may cause serious physical injury due to the prevailing pressure and temperature.
Work safely on the hydraulic system
The hydraulic system could be under high pressure. Do not work on the hydraulic system without:
· releasing the pressure from the hydraulic system,
· switching off the electronic control system,
· switch the tractor off, remove the key from the ignition,
· engage the parking brake of the tractor,
· wait for all machine parts to come to a standstill before you start with the adjustments,
· wear protective clothing, such as safety gloves and shoes,
· carefully follow the instructions given.
Friction with these materials could cause physical injury.
Protect the environment
Spreading a too high dose of materials outside of the field edge, especially on water surface, creates a heavy burden on the environment. Protect the environment by applying a correct application rate in a correct working manner.
Work with a closed cabin
Fertiliser dust can blow indoors through open windows, doors or other openings. Moreover, the sound level is higher in an open cabin. It is therefore recommended to always work with a closed cabin with active carbon filters in the air inlets. Fertiliser dust and a high sound level can cause physical damage.

The exact spreading pattern can be found in the (online) spreading chart service on the website or via the free application (App) for mobile phones with an iOs and/or Android operating system. The chart will provide information about the fertiliser to which this chart relates, including the settings you need to perform in respect of your spreader: dosing setting, discharge point, flowrate, vane combination and angle of the spreader.
The spreading pattern is determined by the selected application rate and the required driving speed. The position that would most likely provide the best spreading pattern is given in the third column, Discharge Point, of the spreading chart.
Always check the accuracy of the discharge point by conducting spreading pattern tests (tray test).
TIP Set the spreader angle before you fill the hopper. It is easier to adjust the top link if the hopper is empty.
Check the position again after the hopper has been filled!
If the inclination is at 4 o of 8 o, the spreader area slides further behind the spreader.

results.question: Which appropriate measures for road transport should be taken when stopping work?
results.model_answer:
The correct answer is:
When transporting a machine on the road, you must take the following measures to prevent damage or injury:

1. Make sure the tractor and machine are in good working order.
2. Check that all parts are securely attached and are not loose.
3. Ensure the parking brake of the tractor is engaged.
4. Switch off the electronic control system and the tractor.
5. Remove the key from the ignition.
6. Wait for all machine parts to come to a standstill before you start with the adjustments.
7. Wear protective clothing, such as safety gloves and shoes.
8. Check that the dosing units are closed.

results.question: What are the detailed technical specifications and bandwidth capabilities of different ISOBUS communication protocol versions compatible with the IsoMatch Tellus system?
results.model_answer:
The ISO 11786 in cab connection is a standard cable for connecting to the tractor. The IsoMatch power cable set is an optional item with the IsoMatch control box.
The IsoMatch Tellus GO terminal is a device that can be connected to the tractor via the 9-point plug "Input IM Tellus" cable, supplied as a standard item.
The IsoMatch Wireless is a system for connecting to the tractor via the 9-pins in Cab cable between your tractor and the IsoMatch control box.
The IsoMatch Eye is an accessory that enables connecting several cameras to the IsoMatch Tellus and the IsoMatch Tellus GO terminal.
The IsoMatch MultiEye is an accessory for better visibility, day and night. The camera can be connected to the IsoMatch Tellus and IsoMatch Tellus GO terminal.
The IsoMatch Grip is a control unit on which most of the machine functions used can be operated centrally with one handle. This is available in addition to the ISO tractor or ISOMatch control box.
Handle control
While working attention and visibility is often required to follow the work process. If operating buttons can be located by the sense of touch reaction speed  can be increased and operating mistakes avoided. By locating the control buttons on the handle by touch while you are looking where you are driving system control can remain focussed.
The IsoMatch Tellus GO terminal is a device that can be connected to the tractor via the 9-point plug "Input IM Tellus" cable, supplied as a standard item.
Other connections are made via the "Input IM Tellus" cable, supplied as a standard item.

results.question: What is the maximum acceptable 'chunk' size of fertilizer in mm to prevent blockage?
results.model_answer:
The maximum acceptable chunk size of fertiliser is 10% of the quantity distributed in the centre behind the spreader (= 100%). This means that the fertiliser granules are not too large to be evenly spread over a working width of 24 metres. If the fertiliser granules are larger than 10%, they can block the spreader or distort the spreading pattern.
The ExactLine is used for border spreading from the sprayer tramline, and has an overlap of 0% with the outermost work area on the field edge. The ExactLine provides a very good border spreading pattern with an optimal balance between profit and the environment.
A broad headland is desirable in order to make the connection to the headland before turning in from the pass. The headland will act as the field boundary and is saved in GEOCONTROL.
The maximum acceptable loss over the field edge is determined by environmental standards. INDICATION
INDICATION
[Image]
The ExactLine with tramlines
[Image: ExactLine]
ExactLine
[Image: ExactLine]
108
The ExactLine is used for border spreading from the sprayer tramline.
The ExactLine provides a very good border spreading pattern with an optimal balance between profit and the environment.
The ExactLine has to be tested. Do not perform this test next to the ditch, rather mark a line behind which the fictive ditch will be.
Operation
 Drive along the field edge when one-sided boundary spreading and send the flow of fertiliser granules with the hydraulic border spreading plate (optional extra).
Direction ( 1 ) (environmental setting)
Spread less to the field edge.
This will decrease the loss over the field edge, but the cover will not be as good
Direction ( 9 ) (yield setting)
Spread more to the field edge.
Cover is better, but the loss is greater
The maximum acceptable loss in the ditch is determined by environmental standards. In order to comply with the standard the quantity of fertiliser spread beyond the field edge must be a maximum of 10% of the quantity distributed in the centre behind the spreader (= 100%). Test if the border spreading plate (optional extra) door de test therefore always before hand as described in
 paragraph »Testing the spreading pattern of the hydraulic border spreading plate« on page 84.
[Image]
109
===Page 110===

Use in the field
Procedure with hydraulic border spreading plate
[Image]
[Image]
110
Left and right border spreading is possible with the hydraulic border spreading plate.
 Switch the tractor off, remove the keys from the ignition and engage the parking brake of the tractor.
 Disconnect the right or left spreading disc by sliding the connector to the right. Secure the connector with a lock clip.
 Lower the border spreading plate.
 Check that the vanes do not touch the border spreading plate!
 Adjust the spreader based on the details given in the spreading chart for the desired working width and the instructions given in the 'One-sided boundary spreading' chapter (height of the spreading disc = 75 cm above the troughs).
 Place 1 trough in the middle of the tractor tracks. The driving track must be half a working width from the fictive ditch.
INDICATION Position the troughs horizontally with a spirit level!
 Divide the additional 6 buckets on the one side of the track over the actual working width of the spreader.
The actual width is twice the size of the effective working width!
If you want to spread over a working width of 24 metres, place the buckets at 24/6 metres = 4 metres.
[Image]
